ROW.title: Letter from A. U. Quint
ROW.description:
Aspersions on character. Letter to Gurdon W. Wattles from A. U. Quint regarding a conversation with G. C. Porter of the Omaha Bee Newspaper. 1 sheet previously folded in sixths. Text reads as follows: Bankers Mutual Casualty Co. Manhattan Building Des Moines, Iowa
Mar. 28-98.
G. W. Wattles, Essq.,
C/o Union National Bank
Omaha, Nebr.
Dear Sir:-\-\-\-
During the day yesterday I was called upon by Mr. G. C. Porter, of your city who gave me to understand that he was representing the Board of Directors, or a Committee of the Board of Directors of the Exposition Company, and was making inquiries concerning your good self. He finally told me what seemed to be his idea of the situation. Of course, I knew nothing about the condition of things in any way. I took, occasion, however, to disabuse his mind of several idea that he seemed to be entertaining, and I can assure you that the interview did not result in any way to your discredit. I have always felt somewhat inclined to extend a good word in favor of my friends in so far as circumstances permit, and the facts will warrant.
Will take great pleasure in accommodating you in any way possible, realizing that my efforts would be reciprocated.
Yours very truly,
A. U. Quint
ROW.creator: Quint, A. U.

ROW.title: Notes on Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition
ROW.description: Aspersions on character. Notes written by Gurdon W. Wattles. References to Wattles, Gurdon W.; Rosewater, Edward; Porter G. C.; 7 pages previously folded in hirds. First 3 pages of text read as follows: [Page 1] At the public meeting called at the Commercial Club Rooms on ___ to effect a preliminary organization of the Trans Mississippi and International Exposition some one unknown to me professed my name as a member of the board of directors. I had not at that time subscribed [?] to the stock but my name was put on the list for $100 unknown to me and I was elected as one of the elven directors. I was not present at this meeting and had not in any manner solicited or suggested my election. When the board met to organize on ___ I nominated Mr. J. T. Lindsay as President and he would have been unanimously elected but he declined to accept. Others were proposed but declined. At last after voting unanimously for my election [?] I conceded to accept temporarily the place. On numerous occasions I asked to be relieved but my request was refused. When the permanent organization was agreed upon in an interview in [Page 2] The Omaha Bee on ___ I advocated the election as president of some prominent and well known citizen like Senator Chars. T. Manderson and declined to serve longer in the position. In this and subsequent interviews I outlined the organization substantially as it was afterwards made. A committee was appointed by me at a meeting on ___ to nominate permanent officers. This committee consisted of E. Rosewater, Frank Murphy. A short time before this committee was to report to the full board I was informed by Mr. Lindsay that some on had made charges against me concerning my business record in Carroll Iowa. I at once placed in Wm. Lindsay's hands such evidence as I had at hand concerning the falsity of these charges and they were [illegible] before the nominating committee and I was informed that after condemnation [Page 3] I was unanimously nominated for the position of president. When the committee reported to the full board Mr. Lindsay took occasion to review the charges that had been made and to say that the committee had unanimously concluded they were false and that I was the best man for the place. When the Executive Committee was organized it soon became evident that Mr. Rosewater and Mr. Hitchcock could not agree on any matters of business and their frequent dispatches retarded all transactions until I finally expressed myself in forcible language regarding their actions. Soon after this Mr. Hitchcock retired from the committee and Mr. Rosewater began to advocate numerous proposition to which meeting I nor the other members of the committee could agree. First he proposed the holding of the exposition in 1898 and proposed thatit be postponed tilll 1899. He opposed all steps to
ROW.creator: Wattles, Gurdon W.

ROW.title: Letter from Grace to Rummy, June 19, 1920
ROW.description: Letter to Rummy from Grace. Wattles, Gurdon W. - Miscellaneous papers. 1 sheet previously folded in quarters. Text Reads: LOCUST VALLEY, LONG ISLAND GLEN COVE, 740 P.S. Kay sends her best. PIPING ROCK CLUB June 19 '20. 12.30 A.M. Dearest Rummy: Well, here we are to-gether again, meaning Kay & I of course. First of all, I must say that I hope you will be able to read this scrawl, but this pen is just abominable & I can't write with it at all. Blunt called for me yesterday afternoon & stayed at [page 2] The house while we played some new records. I brought a whole pile with me & I wish you'd seen the stack of music I brought. I picked out alot [sic.] of the old ones too & brought about all the music I own. We had a fine ride to Oyster Bay, went along Motar Parkway and did some speeding & altogether had a fine time. Blunt said that he is not going to take me home at that speed. (Who said that?) Last night Tom Fraser was over for dinner, because at the last minute, the brother of the [page 3] other girl who is with us, couldn't come until to-day, so we were shy a man. Hence Tom came to the rescue. After dinner we saw a movie called “The Diamond Necklace.” It was terrible, no point to it at all. Then we took up the rug in the hall, started the vic going & danced until eleven-thirty. We came over here about an hour ago. Carmen (the other gir) & Donald, one of the boys are playing tennis. Kay & I have been playing & singing, as usual, then sat out in the sun, while it was shining just [page 4] came in to get warm. [Illegible] & Blunt are out playing golf & Mrs. Doubleday will be here in a few min. then we are all going to have lunch to-gether. Oh, I must tell you, yesterday on the way over Blunt told me about having to play golf this morning with his aunt & not knowing how he was going to tear himself away from me for that long. And when we got to the house, his aunt said "Well, Blunt did you break the sad news to Grace about to-morrow morning. I guess she'll survive all right but I don't know about you." Now what do you think about that? Well, Margie, not a word, but I think Blunt really does like me, from all the things he has said, as well as things Kay & her aunt say. Well I know. I like him [illegible] And he's promised to write to me. Mrs. Doubleday has arrived so will have to write [illegible] in my next. Loads of love, Grace.

ROW.title: "Little Sod Shanty on the Plains" Sheet Music
ROW.description:
Sheet music for "The Little Sod Shanty on the Plains," a song written for the Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition. Cover includes images of a shanty and of the Nebraska State Building on Bluff Tract. Text, including lyrics, reads as follows: "Dedicated to THE FRATERNAL UNION OF AMERICA F. F. ROOSE, Supreme President, Omaha, Neb. THE SOD SHANDY: A Trans-Mississippi Souvenir. NEBRASKA BUILDING, TRANS-MISSISSIPPI EXPOSITION, 1898.
Published by Morte Parsons, 1810 St. Mary's Avenue, Omaha, Neb.
THE LITTLE SOD SHANTY ON THE PLAINS.
A TRANS-MISSISSIPPI SONG.
Words and Music by MORTE PARSONS.
Copyrighted 1898.
Far away out west, upon Nebraska's prairies, We came nigh thirty happy years ago; Since then my wife and I have been a toiling From morn til night in summer and in snow.
We've not been very stylish or progressive, Nor travelled much to spend our scanty gains; We have labored hard, yet lived in health and plenty In our little old shanty on the plains.
You may sing of love in bardic story, olden, Or the meadow's breath, sweet scented with the rains, But you ne'er can sweep the mem'ries sweet and golden, From the little old sod shanty on the plains.
But...... now the times have changed out in Nebraska; That old shanty mouldered in the long ago; We have now a mansion large enough for twenty Of our relative and friends who come and go;
And we're going to have the grandest Exposition That this busy, gay old world has ever seen, And they're coming, for we give to them a welcome To the gates of Omaha, Nebraska's Queen."
You may sing and talk of fairs and expositions, Of the war and brutal conduct of old Spain, But the world had better look for transportation To the Trans-Mississippi on the plains."
ROW.creator: Parsons, Morte

ROW.title: Closing Exercises Invitation
ROW.description: Invitation to Closing Exercises held in the Auditorium at 3 p.m. on October 31, and dinner at the North Cafe at 6 p.m. Printed on white notecard with black ink.
ROW.creator: Wattles, Gurdon W.

ROW.title: Peace Jubilee Dinner Menu
ROW.description:
Peace Jubilee Dinner Menu. Formal menu with envelope. Bound with white satin ribbon in top left corner. Cover imprinted with gold embossed seal of the United States and U.S. Flags in color. Interior pages include image of U.S. Government Building and Menu printed over image of Twin Tower Restaurants from vantage point of east end of the lagoon. Back Cover embossed with gold exposition seal. Interior text reads as follows: "Peace Jubilee Dinner in honor of The President of the United States. The Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition, Omaha. Wednesday, October twelfth, 1898."
"Menu. Blue Points, Celery. Clear Green Turtle, Olives, Radishes. Planked Whitefish, with fine Herbs, Dressed Cucumbers. Braised Lamb Chops, French Peas. Sauterne. Presidential Punch. Roast Canvasback Duck with Cresses, Hominy. Champagne. Lettuce Salad. Ice Cream in Forms. Cakes. Fruits. Brie Cheese. Crackers. Coffee.

ROW.title: Peace Jubilee Souvenir Programme with note
ROW.description: Peace Jubilee Program. 1 program with envelope. Includes hadwritten list of day's events on Union National Bank stationary. Details of daily exercises are listed, including those for Civil Government Day on October 14, Children's Jubilee Day on October 15, President's Day on October 12, Army and Navy Day on October 13, Mayors' Day on October 10, and Governors' Day on October 11. Participants include Chief Justice Fuller; Secretary of the Treasury, Lyman J Gage; Jas. Wilson, Secretary of Agriculture; C. N. Bliss, Secretary of the Interior; President William McKinley, Post Master General, Chas. Emory Smith; John D. Long, Sec'y of Navy; Rear Admiral, Geo. Dewey; Rear Admiral, W. T. Sampson; Rear Admiral, W. S. Schley; Russell A. Alger, Secretary of War; Maj. Gen, Joseph Wheeler; Maj. Gen. N.A. Miles; Maj. Gen. W.R. Shafter; and Silas A. Holcomb, Governor of Nebraska. Events include War Balloon Ascension, Illustration of Life-saving Service, Fireworks, Parades, Music by Innes' Band, Sham Battle by Indian Tribes, Lunches, and Dinners.
ROW.keywords: Peace Jubilee,McKinley,Mayors Day,Governors Day,Presidents Day,Army and Navy Day, Civil Government Day, Childrens Jubilee Day

ROW.title: Moorish Palace. A Temple of Art and Amusement
ROW.description:
Moorish Palace. Catalogue. 1 sheet previously folded in eighths. Pamphlet. Text reads as follows: "The Moorish Palace. A Temple of Art and Amusement. Located on East Midway....near Band Plaza. Surmounted by its Moorish domes and minarets it is at once the largest and most imposing structure on the amusement section. In the outside lobby of the Palace there are on exhibition many interesting and amusing features, which are Absolutely Free, Everybody Welcome In The Lobby. Don't fail to see those funny mirrors and the wonderful moving figures in the lobby, Free. [Open this.] The Interior of the Moorish Palace Is at once the most gorgeous and magnificent spectacle on the Grounds, the scene in the Main Hall being grand in the extreme. Three Immense Floors Are devoted to exhibition purposes, being entirely fileld with realistic and striking representations of events and persons. After leaving the
Grand Hall You wander through corridors and passageways, past scenes so realistic and life-like that you feel yourself transported and seem to be actually witnessing the scenes depicted.
The Execution of marie Antoinette Is a masterpiece which beggars description, while
The Fountian of Perennial Youth Is another artistic gem which excites the wonder and admiration of every visitor.
The furnishings and decorations of The Sultan's Harem Were imported at a cost of $2600.
Striking Biblical Scenes, Events in American History, Shakespearian Tableaux, Fairy Lore, Ancient History, Constitute a vast array of masterpieces which attract, delight and instruct.
The Chamber of Horrors Contains many vivid and startling scenes which once seen will never be forgotten.
History of Crime (4 scenes), Assassination of Lincoln, Scalping a Prisoner, Moorish Execution, The Cannibal's Feast And many others. Don't Miss It.
There are many different features and suprises the Moorish Palace, Some of them beautiful beyond description. Scenes that the most refined and artistic tastes can fully appreicate. Then again there are others on the weird and fantastic order, such as'
The Devil's Cave In the Great Dome. The most realistic scene ever produced. A glimpse into Hades. Rocky gorges and crevices, in which lurk imps and devils.
Magical Electrical Effects, Faust Outdone, Be sure you see The Ride on the Razor. Tears, smiles, sighs, and hearty laughs all mingle together in the Moorish Palace.
Remember Three Large Halls Filled with Rare and Beautiful Scenes.
Catalogues free."

ROW.title: Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition, Omaha, U.S.A., June to November, 1898
ROW.description: Promotional pamphlet for Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition. Publicity book for the Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition. Includes images and descriptions of buildings, descriptions of potential attractions, and information about Omaha, Nebraska, for the purpose of advocating the exposition.

ROW.title: Peace Jubilee Luncheon Menu
ROW.description: Menu for President's Day Luncheon, October 12, 1898, during Peace Jubilee Week. Watercolor image of Native American sitting next to a fire and tipis, smoking a pipe. Photograph of U.S. Government Building in gold embossed seal, placed as if emerging from combined smoke from pipe and fire. Text on menu reads as follows: "Menu. Grape Fruit, Consomme, Frogs legs a la Pulette, Breast of Prairie Chicken, Currant Jelly, Waldorf Salad, Neapolitan Ice Cream, Assorted Cake, Small Coffee, Luncheon, Omaha Club, Wednesday, October 12, 1898. Bureau of Entertainment. Trans-Mississippi Exposition. Omaha."

ROW.title: Omaha Day Menu - copy 2
ROW.description: Omaha Day Menu, from dinner held on October 31, 1898, as part of Closing Day exercises. Printed with blue ink on white stock, with gold edging. U.S. Eagle embossed in gold at top with with colorized shield. Text reads as follows: "Omaha Day. Cream of Tomato; Olives; Radishes; Salmon Trout Au Gratin; Potatoes Parisienne; Filet of Beef Braized, Au Madure; Green Peas; Sauterne; Punch Imperial;

ROW.title: Civil Government Day Menu
ROW.description: Civil Government Day Menu, from dinner held on October 14, 1898, as part of Peace Jubilee Week. Printed with blue ink on white stock, with gold edging. U.S. Eagle embossed in gold at top with with colorized shield. Text reads as follows: "Civil Government Day. Bouillon En Tasse, Celery, Broiled Pompano, Maitre D'Hotel, Radishes, Olives, Filet of Beef, Pique Mushrooms, French Peas, Sauterne, Constitutional Punch, Roast Chicken, Au Cresson, Lettuce Salad, Neapolitan Ice Cream, Cakes, Fruits, Coffee, Cigars, Friday, October 14th. Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition."

ROW.title: Daily program for Wednesday, October 19th
ROW.description: Program for Wednesday, October 19, 1898, Nebraska Day, Lead and Zinc Day, Live Stock Men's Day, Live Stock Show, Indian Congress. Activities include live stock exhibit, Omaha Concert Band, Battleship Illinois, fire horses hitched by electricity, Innes and his band, U.S. Signal Corps, U.S. Life Saving Exhibit, Indian War Dance, War Balloon Ascension, and fireworks. 1 sheet previously folded in half

ROW.title: Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition
ROW.description: Scrapbook of clippings of the Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition. Clippings previously mounted on scrapbook pages. Inclues program pages and news articles from Boston Evening Transcript; World Herald. Subjects include The Fountain of Nautilus, souvenir coins, and comemorative postage stamps.

ROW.title: Official Map of the Grounds
ROW.description: Map of Trans-Mississippi Exposition printed in the Omaha Daily Bee, Wednesday June 1, 1898.

ROW.title: United States Stamp for Special Tax - Internal Revenue
ROW.description: Stamp certificate for special tax issued by Internal Revenue Service in the amount of $100. Dated July 1898 - June 1899. 1 sheet previously folded in quarters.

ROW.title: Letter from John Wakefield Regarding Stock Certificates
ROW.description: Letter to Lewis S. Reed from John A. Wakefield regarding receipt of a set of "Notices of Assessment" in Stock Sub #6581 to be donated to Omaha Public Library. 1 sheet previously folded in twelfths; typed transcription.
ROW.creator: Wakefield, John A.

ROW.title: Donation of lease from the Earl of Berks dated 1693
ROW.description: Letter to Robert S. Oberfelder from Secretary of Omaha Public Library acknowledging receipt with thanks of lease from Earl of Berks to Gyles aBaily and Mary Smyth dated 1693 and written on parchement; 1 sheet previously folded in thirds.

ROW.title: Donation of illustrations by John A. Wakefield
ROW.description: Letter to John W. Wakefield from the secretary of the Omaha Public Library Board regarding a resolution of thanks passed and recorded in the minutes of their last meeting for the donation of fine art pictures. Illustrations include: "Fichermans Departure," by Louis Paul Dessur; "Abandoned on New England Coast," by Charles H. Davis; "Opal," by Robert Reid; "Moonrise and Mist," by S. E. Whitteman; "Girl Herding Cows," by E. I. Conse; and "Moonrise Off Cape Ann," by L. H. Meakin." 1 sheet previously folded in thirds.

ROW.title: Donation of Shell Collection
ROW.description: Letter stating that the Omaha Woman's Club will retain $30 for expenses possibly incident to the returning of the Underwood shell collection on temporary display at the Omaha Public Library. Signed by Harriet C. Towne, Mary I. Creigh, Laura Scott, and Edith Tobitt. 1 sheet previously folded in quarters. Typed transcription.
ROW.creator: Towne, Harriet C.; Creigh, Mary I.; Scott, Laura

ROW.title: Receipt of Underwood Shell Collection
ROW.description: Notecard. Receipt of Mrs. Nathan Underwood collection of shells and curios for display at the Omaha Public Library for 1 year. 1 sheet previously folded in half. Typed transcription.
ROW.creator: Tobitt, Edith

ROW.title: Offer to Sell Minerals
ROW.description: Letter to John A Wakefield from J. G. Hiestand. Offer to sell minerals from his collection at a reduced rate, for donation to the Omaha Public Library. 1 sheet previously folded in 25ths; typed transcription.
ROW.creator: Hiestand, J. G.

ROW.title: Mineral Collection
ROW.description: Letter to John A. Wakefield from J. G. Hiestand acknowledging receipt of payment for mineral collection. Includes list of specimens purchased by the Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition committee from J. G. Hiestand and donated to the City of Omaha to be displayed at the Omaha Public Library. Mineral collection includes Blue Quartz Malachite, Malachite Azurite, Malachite Bisbee, Amazon Stone, Topaz, and Phenacite. Contains 2 sheets. 1 sheet previously folded in twelfths; typed transcription. 1 sheet previously folded in 25ths with notes on reverse; typed transcription.
ROW.creator: Hiestand, J. G.

ROW.title: Letter Regarding Donations of Trans-Mississippi Expo Artifacts to Omaha Public Library
ROW.description: Letter to Lewis S. Reed from F. P. Kirkendall. Asks to have a meeting with the Omaha Public Library Board, along with Edward Rosewater and Gurdon W. Wattles, about how best to preserve souvenirs and pictures from the Trans-Mississippi Exposition. 1 sheet previously folded in twelfths.
ROW.creator: Kirkendall, F. P.

ROW.title: Letter Regarding illustrations to be Donated to the Omaha Public Library
ROW.description: Letter to Lewis S. Reed from John A. Wakefield regarding donation of fine arts pictures displayed at the Trans-Mississippi Exposition to the City of Omaha, to be displayed within Exposition museum along with other objects of interest at the Omaha Public Library. 1 sheet previously folded in twelfths.
ROW.creator: Wakefield, John A.

ROW.title: Letter to John A. Wakefield regarding Mineral Collection
ROW.description: Letter to John A. Wakefield from David L. Day regarding purchase of specimens from Hiestand Mineral Collection, later donated to Omaha Public Library. 1 sheet previously folded in twelfths. Typescript with handwritten note.
ROW.creator: Day, David L.

ROW.title: Donation of Exposition Materials to Omaha Public Library
ROW.description: Letter to Lewis S. Reed from John A. Wakefield requesting storage space within Omaha Public Library building for books and records from the exposition. 1 sheet previously folded in twelfths; typed transcription.
ROW.creator: Wakefield, John A.

ROW.title: Letter Regarding Donation of Fine Arts Pictures to Omaha Public LIbrary
ROW.description: Letter to John A. Wakefield from Lewis S. Reed regarding donation of pictures from the Trans-Mississippi & International Exposition to the City of Omaha. States intention to fit up third floor of Omaha Public Library building to commemorate the exposition. One room will be an art gallery; one room will serve as a musueum. 1 sheet previously folded in twelfths.
ROW.creator: Reed, Lewis S.

ROW.title: Letter Regarding Donation of Mineral Collection
ROW.description: Letter from John A. Wakefield regarding donation of mineral specimens comprised in the Hiestand Collection of Minerals to the Omaha Public Library. 1 sheet previously folded in thirds; Typed transcription.
ROW.creator: Wakefield, John A.

ROW.title: Donation of Trans-Mississippi Postage Stamps, Postal Cards, Stock Papers, and Guide Book to Omaha Public Library
ROW.description: Letter of receipt from John A. Wakefield regarding donation of a full set of Trans-Mississippi postage stamps, postal cards, stock papers, and guide book to Omaha Public Library. 1 sheet previously folded in thirds.
ROW.creator: Wakefield, John A.

ROW.title: Commutation Ticket
ROW.description: Commutation ticket. 1 sheet previously folded in half; tickets attached. First page is interior of ticket booklet. Contains photo of man with moustache wearing hat, coat, and bow tie and holding a card printed with the number 3058, and four exposition admission tickets, each printed on blue paper with black text, and numbered sequentially. Second page is exterior of ticket booklet, belonging to 3058 D. Printed on white stock with black text.

ROW.title: "Daily Hint for Leap Year Girl: Exhibit 14"
ROW.description: Newpaper article from February 26, 1908. Recto and verso of clipping. 1 article previously folded. Recto features illustration of a man standing on a "For Rent" sign. Real estate listings on verso.
ROW.creator: George, J. E.

ROW.title: Admission Pass
ROW.description: Pass for Exhibition; George, J. E. 1 pass previously folded in half. Page one is Interior of ticket booklet issued to J. E. George. Contains photo of George wearing hat, coat, and bow tie and holding a card printed with the number 288. Conditions of use listed, along with signature of J. George. Page two is Exterior of ticket booklet issued to J.E. George by the Exhibits Depatment.

ROW.title: Souvenir Program, Peace Jubilee
ROW.description: Peace Jubilee booklet. Bound by satin ribbon within transparent paper cover. Includes programs for Mayors' Day, Monday, Ocotober 10; Governors' Day, Tuesday, October 11; President's Day, Wednesday, October 12; Civil Government Day, Friday, October 14; and Children's Jubilee Day, Saturday October 15. Includes photographs and illustrations.

ROW.title: Color Photographs of the Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition, Omaha, Nebraska
ROW.description: Mounted photograph book containing 12 AAC color photographs by F. A. Rinehart. Photographs include: Grand Court, Looking West; Government Building; Nebraska Building; Horticultural Building; Agricultural Building; Mines Building; Neptune's Fountain; The Midway, The Rialto; The Midway-\-East Avenue; South Facade, Agriculture Building; East End of Grand Court; and Night Illumination of Grand Court. Printed by the Detroit Photographic Company.
ROW.creator: Rinehart, F. A.

ROW.title: Statement and Report of Admissions
ROW.description: Attendance and financial accounts ledger from Exposition. Accounts recorded by date. Cut into sixteenths and mounted on canvas.

ROW.title: Army and Navy Day Program
ROW.description: Program from Army and Navy Day, Thursday, October 13, 1898, during Peace Jubilee Week. Listed activities include: Exercises, Addresses, Lunch, Parades, Ascension of War Balloons, Shame Battle, and Fireworks. Portraits of Army and Navy officials along border, with illustrations of ships and soliders with cannons in the field during battle.

ROW.title: Trans-Mississippi Exposition at Omaha - Illumination of Grounds at Night

ROW.description: Harpers Weekly; Trans-Mississippi grounds. Grand Court at Night, looking west. Liberal and Fine Arts Buildings to the southwest. U.S. Government Building to the west, and Manufactures' building to the north. Light crowd at top of step leading to lagoon. Gondolas and swan boat in lagoon. Framed Print.
ROW.creator: Rogers, W. A.

ROW.creator: Austen, E. J.

ROW.title: Burlington Route Official Bird's - Eye View. The Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition
ROW.caption: Modern Woodman Day at the Trans-Mississippi Exposition, Thursday, Sept. 22. Official Birds-Eye View. The Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition, Omaha, U.S.A., June to November, 1898.
ROW.description: Framed, colorized Burlington Route poster advertising Modern Woodman Day, September 22, 1898. Additional text reads: "Now is the Time to see the Great Exposition. It is in the Zenith of its Glory. Extra-ordinarily Low Round Trip Rates Sept. 21. Also on Sept 22 four Trains Arriving at Omaha Before Noon of that Day. Return Limit. Five Days From Date of Sale.
ROW.creator: Austen, E. J.

ROW.title: North Viaduct
ROW.caption: North Viaduct; Walker & Kimball, Architects
ROW.description: Architect's drawing of North Viaduct by Walker and Kimball. Spectators and performers gathered with camels and horses. Framed illustration.
ROW.creator: Walker, Howard; Kimball, Thomas Rogers

ROW.title: Fountain of Neptune
ROW.description: Illustration of Neptune atop the Fountain of Nautilus in the west end of the lagoon. Fountain turned on. Framed illustration.
ROW.creator: Austen, E. J.

ROW.title: Lagoon with Twin Towers
ROW.description: Colorized illustration of Lagoon with gondolas in water and Twin Tower Restaurants and Grand Colonnade to the east. Framed illustration.
ROW.creator: CHW

ROW.title: Grand Court
ROW.caption: The Grand Court. Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition, Omaha, Nebraska
ROW.description: Framed poster of F.A. Rinehart photo of Grand Court, looking west. Mines & Mining, Liberal Arts, and Fine Arts Buildings to the southwest; U.S. Government Building and balustraded island to the west across the lagoon; Agriculture, Manufactures' and Machinery & Electricity Buildings to the northwest.

ROW.title: Lagoon with Twin Towers
ROW.description: Illustration of east end of Lagoon, with view of Machinery and Electricity Building to the northeast, Twin Tower Restaurants and Grand Colonnade to the east, and Mines and Mining Building to the southeast.

ROW.title: Diploma for Commemorative Medal Awarded to Gurdon W. Wattles
ROW.description: Diploma for Commemorative medal awarded to Gurdon W. Wattles, Director and President in recognition of honorable service. Graphic on diploma includes classical figures and view of west end of Grand Court. Red embossed seal with satin ribbons at bottom of document.

ROW.title: Apiary Building
ROW.caption: Apiary Building; Jno McDonald, Architect
ROW.description: Architect's Illustration of Apiary Building. Crowd gathered in front of building. Framed illustration.
ROW.creator: CHW

ROW.title: Dairy Building
ROW.caption: Dairy Building; F. A. Henninger, Architect
ROW.description: Architect's Illustration of Dairy Building. Crowd gathered in front of building. Framed illustration.
ROW.creator: F.A. Henninger

ROW.title: Official Bird's-Eye View, The Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition
ROW.caption: Official Bird's-Eye View of the Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition. Omaha, U.S.A June to November 1898.
ROW.description: Framed Poster. Images of Individual buildings border bird's - eye view of exposition grounds.
ROW.creator: Austen, E. J.

ROW.title: Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition, Overhead view
ROW.caption: The Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition. Omaha, U.S.A. June to November 1898.
ROW.description: Framed Poster. Bird's - eye view of exposition grounds.
ROW.creator: Austen, E. J.

ROW.title: Notice to Exhibitors and Concessionaires
ROW.description: Framed letter asking all exhibitors and concessionaries to donate materials to the Omaha City Library for a museum space, within the library, dedicated to the exposition. Printed on Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition Letterhead.
ROW.creator: Manderson, C. F.; Lyman, C. W.; and Carpenter, I.

ROW.title: Stock Certificate for Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition
ROW.description: Framed Stock certificate, certifying ownership of exposition shares by the Omaha Public Library, signed by John Wakefield and Gurdon W. Wattles. Green and black printing, with gold embossed seal and red ribbon.

ROW.title: Offical Bird's-Eye View of the Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition
ROW.caption: Offical Bird's-Eye View of the Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition Omaha, U.S.A. June to November, 1898
ROW.description: Bird's - eye view of exposition grounds. Framed Poster.
ROW.creator: Austen, E. J.

ROW.title: Indian Congress Poster - Ahahe and infant, Wichita
ROW.caption: Ahahe Wichita
ROW.description: Colorized reproduction of Rinehart photo. Indian Congress Studio Portrait poster. Woman with Infant. Ahahe of the Wichita tribe. Red border with illustrations of Native American objects.
ROW.creator: Rinehart, F.A.

ROW.title: Indian Congress Poster - Chief Geronimo (Guyiatle), Apache
ROW.caption: Chief Geronimo (Guyiatle) Apache
ROW.description: Colorized reproduction of Rinehart photo. Indian Congress Studio Portrait poster. Man wrapped in colorful blanket with headdress. Chief Geronimo (Guyiatle), Chiricahua Apache. Red border with illustrations of Native American objects.
ROW.creator: Rinehart, F.A.

ROW.title: Indian Congress Poster - Chief Grant Richards, Tonkawa
ROW.caption: Chief Grant Richards - Tonkawa
ROW.description: Colorized reproduction of Rinehart photo. Indian Congress Studio Portrait poster. Profile of man holding feathers. Chief Grant Richards, Tonkawa. Red border with illustrations of Native American objects.
ROW.creator: Rinehart, F.A.

ROW.title: Indian Congress Poster - Chief Red Cloud, Sioux
ROW.caption: Chief Red Cloud, Sioux
ROW.description: Colorized reproduction of Rinehart photo. Indian Congress Studio Portrait poster. Man holding pipe. Chief Red Cloud, Sioux. Red border with illustrations of Native American objects.
ROW.creator: Rinehart, F.A.

ROW.title: Indian Congress Poster - Chief Wets-It, Assinniboine
ROW.caption: Chief Wets-It, Assinniboine
ROW.description: Colorized reproduction of Rinehart photo. Indian Congress Studio Portrait poster. Man wearing headdress and holding shield. Chief Wets-It, Assinniboine. Red border with illustrations of Native American objects.
ROW.creator: Rinehart, F.A.

ROW.title: Indian Congress Poster - Gov. Diego Narango, Santa Clara Pueblo
ROW.caption: Gov. Diego Narango, Santa Clara Pueblo
ROW.description: Colorized reproduction of Rinehart photo. Indian Congress Studio Portrait poster. Man in profile. Governor Diego Narango, Santa Clara Pueblo. Red border with illustrations of Native American objects.
ROW.creator: Rinehart, F.A.

ROW.title: Views of the Trans-Mississippi Exposition
ROW.description: Aluminum Cover reads "TME OMAHA 1898." Contains 18 photographs. Last pages blank, with signature in pencil that reads: "Jno Fremont Bassett, Aluminum."
ROW.creator: Rinehart, F.A.

ROW.title: Omaha Trans-Mississippi Exposition 1898
ROW.description: Aluminum Cover reads "OMAHA TME 1898"; title page missing; early photos showing scaffolding. Contains 14 pictures.
ROW.creator: Rinehart, F.A.

ROW.title: List of Letters Regarding Donations to Omaha Public Library
ROW.description: List of 14 letters regarding donation of Trans-Mississippi Exposition Materials to the Omaha Public Library. Donors include John A. Wakefield, Lewis S. Reed, Harriet C. Towne, Mary I. Creigh, Laura Scott, Edith Tobitt, F. P. Kirkendall, J. G. Hiestand, and David L. Day.
ROW.creator: Omaha Public Library

ROW.title: Oklahoma Day Program
ROW.description: Oklahoma Day invitation and program, Friday, September 16. Program exercises include Music by First Regiment Band, Welcome Address by Silas A. Holcomb, Governor of Nebraska; Response by C. M. Barnes, Governor of Oklahoma; Address by Gurdon W. Wattles; Address by J. C. Roberts; and Address by Major E. A. Woodson, U.S. Army-Indian Agent for Cheyenne and Arapahoe Indians.

ROW.title: Official Bird's Eye View, The Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition
ROW.caption: Official Bird's-Eye View The Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition. Omaha, U.S.A. June to November 1898.
ROW.description: Poster. Illustration of bird's - eye view of Exposition. Cut in quarters and mounted on canvas. Final image is a composite of the four scans together. Remnants of a pressed four-leaf clover positioned over Manufactures Building.
ROW.creator: Austen, E. J.

ROW.title: Peace Jubilee Program
ROW.description: Souvenir program from Peace Jubilee. October 10-15, 1898. Front and back cover with Navy page only. Bound by satin ribbon.

ROW.title: Official Postal Card - Horticulture Bldg.
ROW.description: Official one-cent postal card featuring the Horticulture Building. View 1 of 10 printed by U.S. Postal Card Co. Engraved and printed by Chicago Colortype Co. Includes image of woman pruning shrubbery, signatures of Furdon W. Wattles and John A. Wakefield, and Exposition seal. Verso and recto. Back of card includes portrait of Thomas Jefferson.

ROW.title: Invitation to the Banquet of Old Time Telegraphers Association and the Society of United States Military Telegraph Corps.
ROW.description: Invitation to banquet to the Old Time Telegraphers Association and the Society of the U. S. Military Telegraph Corps. At the Markel Cafe on Thursday, September 15 at 7 p.m, by W. W. Umsted, secretary, and J.J. Dickey, President.

ROW.title: Wakefield Scrapbook Volume 01
ROW.description: Scrapbook of clippings of the Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition from the Omaha Bee, the World Herald, and various local news sources. Article dates are November 25th, 1895 to December 21st, 1896.

ROW.title: Wakefield Scrapbook Volume 02
ROW.description: Scrapbook of clippings of the Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition from the Omaha Bee, the World Herald, and various local news sources. Article dates are December 22nd 1896 to August 18th 1897.

ROW.title: Wakefield Scrapbook Volume 03
ROW.description: Scrapbook of clippings of the Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition from the Omaha Bee, the World Herald, and various local news sources. Article dates are August 19th, 1897 to February 10th, 1898.

ROW.title: Wakefield Scrapbook Volume 04
ROW.description: Scrapbook of clippings of the Trans-Mississippi and International Exposition from the Omaha Bee, the World Herald, and various local news sources. Article dates are October 8th, 1898 to November 25th, 1898.
